title: Facebook Hires Its First Chief Compliance Officer
summary: The social-media company says Henry Moniz, who has been the chief compliance officer and chief audit executive at ViacomCBS, will start on Feb. 8. Facebook Inc. has hired its first chief compliance officer, as the social media company faces increasing scrutiny from regulators.

title: Robinhood, Facing Ire on Many Fronts, Defends Its App to Regulators
summary: Online brokerage accused of aggressively marketing to inexperienced investors. Robinhood Markets Inc. on Friday told Massachusetts regulators that it doesn't take advantage of inexperienced customers, capping a wild week during which the popular online brokerage drew fierce ire for doing just the opposite: standing in customers' way.

title: No Good Vaccine Deed
summary: The Biden team shows no gratitude to the man who sped up the Covid shots.. Johnson & Johnson and Novavax this week reported that their vaccines were effective in clinical trials, and what fortunate timing. The U.S. urgently needs a supply boost. But at this juncture it's also worth noting how former Operation Warp Speed chief Moncef Slaoui positioned the Biden Administration for a vaccine triumph.

title: Nasdaq Tech Chief Credits Cloud With Helping Manage Market Frenzies
summary: Cloud-based computing capacity helps the exchange quickly adjust to wild market swings. Nasdaq Inc.'s enterprise technology leader said an aggressive cloud strategy that proved its mettle during the pandemic helped gird the exchange operator's systems for shocks like this week's market turmoil.

title: Hong Kong's Escape Routes
summary: Beijing retaliates after Britain offers refuge from growing tyranny.. To its eternal credit, the British government is honoring its promise to its former colonial subjects by offering a path to citizenship for Hong Kongers who hold British National (Overseas) passports and their family members. The need for such refuge became clearer on Friday as China retaliated by announcing that China will no longer recognize BN(O) passports as a valid form of identification or travel documentation.

title: A Pass for Kevin Clinesmith
summary: A FISA judge gives a former FBI agent a slap on the wrist.. How can the American people take the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court seriously when it doesn't do so itself? That's our view of Friday's sentencing of former FBI lawyer Kevin Clinesmith, who admitted to falsifying evidence submitted to the court for a warrant to spy on onetime Trump foreign-policy adviser Carter Page.

title: Wells Fargo CEO Charles Scharf Gets a 12% Pay Cut
summary: The bank will pay him about $20.3 million for 2020, down from $23 million.. Wells Fargo & Co. paid its top executive about $20.3 million last year, a drop of 12% from a year earlier.

title: Businessman Bernie Moreno Likely to Enter Ohio Senate Contest
summary: Longtime donor is one of several Republicans considering a bid to succeed retiring GOP Sen. Rob Portman. WASHINGTON-Ohio businessman Bernie Moreno is likely to seek the Republican nomination to succeed retiring GOP Sen. Rob Portman in 2022, according to people familiar with the matter, adding a twist to a contest that could help determine control of the Senate.

title: 'Religion and the Rise of Capitalism' Review: God and Mammon
summary: An economist looks at how the 'dismal science' has kept pace with trends in American Christianity.. The biggest cheerleaders for the Enlightenment in our era-Steven Pinker, for example-often imagine it as having occurred in a religious vacuum. They forget, or appear to forget, that Isaac Newton was animated by his Christian belief that God had created an intelligible universe; and they sidestep the Christian foundations of political rights and other key Enlightenment principles.

title: Politics: Of Markets and Morals
summary: Determining how much to regulate the freedom to buy and sell touches deep questions of value.. One of the classic criticisms leveled against capitalism by its adversaries holds that market economies, left unchecked, tend to reduce all of life to a series of transactions. Marxists reject markets altogether on the grounds that they encourage selfishness; ultratraditionalist Catholics worry that markets commodify morality; and social democrats, though tolerant of markets because the welfare state has to be paid for, believe that large parts of life should be sealed off from market values.

title: Stocks Fall 2% as GameStop Frenzy Continues
summary: Dow, S&P 500 end worst week since October with sharp declines. U.S. stocks fell sharply Friday in their worst week since October, reflecting concern over the lingering economic impact of the coronavirus and ripples from the trading frenzy that has swept Wall Street this month.

title: Day-Trader Mania Will Challenge SEC Under Gensler
summary: Marriage of social media and online-trading platforms brings more investors in to the market but amplifies risks. WASHINGTON-The trading mania around shares of companies like GameStop Corp. this week poses a dilemma for Gary Gensler, the Biden administration's choice to head the Securities and Exchange Commission: While broadening investor participation, the stampede also poses new risks that could spread to other participants.

title: GameStop Was an Enjoyment of Crowds
summary: Players weren't 'investors' and they didn't invent a new road to prosperity and wealth creation.. If little-informed members of the public can be egged on by social media to storm the Capitol, why can't they be egged on to storm GameStop stock? They can be and were. The mistake, which will nevertheless be made, is treating an episode unique and singular in many respects as heralding a trend.

title: They Want to Put a Highway in Lead Belly's Backyard
summary: A plan to extend I-49 through a historically black neighborhood has divided Shreveport, La.. Fights over whether to build freeways through city neighborhoods may seem like a thing of the past. It has been 65 years since Jane Jacobs successfully rallied opposition to Robert Moses's plans for a highway through Manhattan's Washington Square Park and 60 years since the Chrysler Freeway sliced through Detroit. But a version of this old fight is dividing Shreveport, La.

title: GameStop Stock, Reddit and Robinhood: What You Need to Know
summary: How traders online drove the videogame retailer's stock to new highs and caused a crazy week in markets. The stock of videogame retailer GameStop started 2021 at $18.84. On Friday, its share price traded above $340. And it isn't the only surprising stock seeing big gains. Below, we catch you up on the latest developments in the GameStop stock market mania.

title: Reddit-Fueled Stock Rallies Boost Some Bond Prices
summary: Bonds tied to AMC, American Airlines and other companies have risen thanks in part to this week's stock market madness. This week's Reddit-fueled stock market frenzy is having some spillover effects on the corporate bond market.

title: Covid-19 Vaccines and How They Work
summary: Resume Subscription. Seven coronavirus vaccines are rolling out across six continents to slow the global pandemic, and more are in late-stage testing. The shots use different technologies to help people mount the molecular defenses that can fend off Covid-19.

title: NY Fed Paper: Easy Monetary Policy Does Little to Cut Racial Income Inequality
summary: In new research, regional Fed bank economists says ultra-easy monetary policy may accentuate inequalities. Ultra-easy monetary policy may not help reduce racial economic disparities anywhere near as much as many now believe, new research from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said.

title: Elon Musk Joins GameStop Melee With More Jabs at Short Sellers
summary: Tesla CEO can trigger gains in other companies' shares, though they can be fleeting. Retail investors are taking short sellers to the cleaners at least for now, and Elon Musk is loving it.

title: Chevron Posts Quarterly Loss to Cap Worst Year Since 2016
summary: Like its peers, the oil giant endured a tough 2020 as the coronavirus pandemic crushed demand for fossil fuels. Chevron Corp. posted its third consecutive quarterly loss Friday to close its worst year since 2016, as the global pandemic continues to weigh on the oil-and-gas industry and cloud hopes for renewed economic growth in 2021.

title: Macron Calls for Regulation of Social Media to Stem 'Threat to Democracy'
summary: French leader says West needs to act to rein in political extremism. PARIS-French President Emmanuel Macron called for international regulation to curb the spread of ideological extremism in Western democracies, chiding tech companies and political correctness for allowing it to flourish.

title: John Chaney, Temple's Hall of Fame Basketball Coach, Dies
summary: Chaney led Temple to 17 NCAA Tournament appearances over 24 seasons. PHILADELPHIA-John Chaney, one of the nation's leading basketball coaches and a commanding figure during a Hall of Fame career at Temple, died Friday. He was 89.

title: Gold Rush
summary: This whiskey sour variation looks particularly dashing served with a large chunk of ice. To explore and search through all our recipes, check out the new WSJ Recipes page.

title: Black Market Sling
summary: Developed by bartender Phil Ward for Death & Co., this versatile drink works with multiple spirits. To explore and search through all our recipes, check out the new WSJ Recipes page.

title: After Nearly Seven Years Held Captive by Boko Haram, Chibok Girl Escapes
summary: Officials say young woman was in group liberated from jihadist kidnappers by military offensive. At least one of the more than 100 young women still missing after their abduction by Islamist militant group Boko Haram in the Nigerian town of Chibok almost seven years ago managed to escape her captors this week, according to family members and local officials.

title: Southside
summary: This drink is also refreshing lengthened with ice and soda water, in what's known as a Southside Fizz. To explore and search through all our recipes, check out the new WSJ Recipes page.

title: Manhattan
summary: "It's a classic for a reason," Mr. Buhler said, citing this drink's "simplicity and straightforward flavor profile". To explore and search through all our recipes, check out the new WSJ Recipes page.

title: Cheers for Jeers (Saturday Crossword, January 30)
Thinking Outside the Box (Saturday Cryptic Puzzle, January 30)
Sounds From the Future
summary: Arnold Schoenberg's 'Pierrot Lunaire' ('Moonstruck Pierre') so defied the melodic conventions of classical music that it initially even perplexed Stravinsky..

title: FISA vs. Liberty
summary: A surveillance judge clarifies that the FBI can falsify evidence without much fear of punishment.. The government employees of the "resistance" who never accepted Donald Trump as our president have finally performed a useful public service. Together with the judges of the U.S. Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, they have demonstrated for all Americans how easy it is to turn the spying tools of the federal government against domestic political opponents.

title: Letter to Pimco Executives Alleges Discrimination Toward Women
summary: Former, current female employees request better pay and promotions for women. Current and former employees of Pacific Investment Management Co. wrote to the investment firm's senior executives alleging a pattern of abusive and discriminatory behavior toward women and urging them to take steps to fix gaps in pay and promotions.

title: Pakistan to Challenge Release of Man Convicted in Daniel Pearl Murder
summary: Attorney general says authorities will pursue legal options to keep Omar Sheikh in prison after Supreme Court ruling. ISLAMABAD-Pakistan will try to keep in prison the man previously convicted of the 2002 kidnapping and murder of Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl, the country's attorney general said, as the government challenges a court order for his release.

title: Covid-19 Case Decline in Nursing Homes Offers Hopeful Sign
summary: Latest drop-off may be an early signal that the shots are working, say industry officials. Covid-19 cases in nursing homes have been declining for several weeks, raising hope among industry and state officials that vaccinations are starting to have an impact in the hard-hit facilities.

title: Chevron Emerges From Exxon's Shadow
summary: Chevron's careful strategy has helped it stay off radars of activist investors and regulators. In a sector facing uncomfortable questions about the future, it helps to stay out of the spotlight. Chevron certainly managed to do that as its competitor Exxon Mobil faces scrutiny from activist investors and securities regulators.

title: Are Fancy Cocktails Worth the Fuss? A Guide to the WFH Happy Hour
summary: With a capsule bar of just three bottles, you can make innumerable drinks. But for some, even that is asking too much. Two tipplers debate: Do we really have the bandwidth to mix a proper cocktail right now?. For the recurring series, That's Debatable, we take on a contentious issue of the day and present two spirited arguments-one in favor and other emphatically opposed. Previous installments from the series are here.

title: Mall Owner Shares Surge Thanks to Small Investors' Short Squeeze
summary: Macerich and Tanger Factory Outlet Centers popped after online traders identified the two as sell targets by hedge funds and other professional investors. Shares of two beleaguered shopping-center owners soared this week, joining a broader rally among stocks that individual investors have powered higher in their battle with professional money managers.

title: Cuomo Says New York City's Indoor Dining Can Restart Feb. 14
summary: Capacity indoors to be capped at 25%; decision based on decrease in Covid-19 positivity rate. New York City restaurants are getting a Valentine from the governor, but some restaurant owners aren't feeling the love.

title: How the Wisdom of Crowds Became the Anarchy of the Mob
summary: Thousands of Americans are being mobilized by social-media algorithms that amplify fringe ideas. The results have real-world impact.. This was the week that the stock market became the stonks market. For those of you unaware, "stonks" is an internet meme, an absurdist play on the word "stock" that's now almost unavoidable on social media. On Jan. 26, Elon Musk, recently the world's richest man, tweeted "Gamestonk!!", and received more than 200,000 likes. It included a link to the WallStreetBets forum on the internet message-board platform, Reddit.

title: After Scripted Rollouts of Executive Orders, Biden's Task Gets Harder
summary: President has spent his first 10 days on preplanned policy moves, but now he has to negotiate a Covid-19 aid package on Capitol Hill. WASHINGTON-President Biden's first 10 days in office have unfolded with a precise choreography of executive orders, policy announcements, daily press briefings and scripted signings from the Oval Office, early signs of how he and his top aides would like to manage White House operations.

title: Cryptocurrency Platforms Struggle With Demand From WallStreetBets Fervor
summary: Coinbase's website went down on a day of intense trading in cryptocurrencies. A swell of cryptocurrency trading coincided with a major bitcoin exchange outage and led to curbs on other platforms, mirroring the difficulties traditional brokers have had with a frenzy of stock-market activity.

title: President's Brother Draws Scrutiny for Law-Firm Work
summary: White House says the president is committed to having an ethical administration after questions about his younger brother's business dealings. An advertisement touting a law firm's ties to President Biden's brother prompted the White House on Friday to state that Mr. Biden is committed to overseeing an ethical administration.

title: The Constitution Can Crack Section 230
summary: Tech companies think the statute allows them to censor with impunity. The law is seldom so simple.. Section numbers of federal statutes rarely stir the soul, but one of them, 230, stirs up much fear, for it has seemed to justify censorship. Relying on it, tech companies including Google and Twitter increasingly pull the plug on disfavored posts, websites and even people. Online moderation can be valuable, but this censorship is different. It harms Americans' livelihoods, muzzles them in the increasingly electronic public square, distorts political and cultural conversations, influences elections, and limits our freedom to sort out the truth for ourselves.

title: SEC to Review Brokers' Restrictions on GameStop, AMC Trading
summary: Securities regulators say they are on the lookout for potentially manipulative trading. Securities regulators said Friday they plan to closely review the actions of some brokerage firms that restricted investors' ability to trade volatile stocks such as GameStop Corp. this week.

title: James Baldwin's 'Cultural Appropriation'-and Mine
summary: The great black novelist wrote about whites, but white novelists of his day didn't return the favor.. I was ready to take a punch for James Baldwin. It was spring of 1992, and my one-man play about Baldwin, written at the request of the late actor Reggie Montgomery, had just been given a rehearsed reading at New York's Lincoln Center. Most of the invited audience appeared enthusiastic, but in the foyer a naysayer approached me. Michael Thelwell, then a professor of African-American studies at the University of Massachusetts Amherst, told me many things about what he had just seen, the most polite being "Keep out."

title: A History of Slavery in Art and Artifacts
summary: A new exhibition at Amsterdam's Rijksmuseum examines the Netherlands' role in colonialism and the slave trade.. Art lovers who look back on 17th-century Holland as a golden age, top-heavy with Rembrandts and Vermeers, are about to have their historical vision corrected. Next month, Amsterdam's Rijksmuseum-the national gallery of the Netherlands and the greatest depository of Dutch masterpieces-will take a probing look at a more sinister side of the country's past in a new exhibition, "Slavery: Ten True Stories."

title: AstraZeneca's Covid-19 Vaccine Wins EU Green Light
summary: Approval is unlikely to quell growing political furor over the shot's effectiveness, production problems and availability. The European Union's drug regulator recommended use of a Covid-19 vaccine from AstraZeneca PLC, but the approval is unlikely to quell growing political furor over its effectiveness, production problems and availability.

title: J&J Covid-19 Vaccine Was 66% Effective in Late-Stage Study
summary: The company plans to seek authorization for the single-dose shot in the U.S. early next month. Johnson & Johnson said its experimental Covid-19 vaccine was 66% effective at protecting people from moderate to severe disease in a large clinical trial, positive results that could pave the way for its deployment across the U.S. within weeks.

title: Why Catalog Brands Like Filson and Lands' End Are Cool Again
summary: A welcome escape from the digital world, those things in your mailbox sell some great stuff-if you know how to shop them. Here, a stylish guide to buying catalog clothes.. HOW MANY screens are in your bedroom-turned-office? We're bombarded by blue light from our laptops and phones as we scroll through emails, Slack chats, Instagram, Twitter or whatever e-comm site that creepily tailored-to-you pop-up ad recommends. Sure, you could get up and take a walk, but here's a less expected antidote to digital overload: Thumb through the catalogs that clog your (actual) mailbox.

title: Fuss Over Central Park Snowy Owl Suggests New Yorkers Give a Hoot
summary: The strange appearance drew a big scene this week, though some worried about attracting too much attention. A half-dozen park rangers flocked to Manhattan's Central Park on Wednesday to control the crowd. Photographers moved in, while onlookers bundled up in hats, gloves and face masks gathered around. The rangers told everyone not to shout, use flash photography or deploy drones to get shots.

title: Shell Ordered to Pay Compensation Over Nigerian Oil Spills
summary: Dutch court also calls for oil giant to install equipment to guard against pipeline leaks. LONDON- Royal Dutch Shell PLC's Nigerian subsidiary has been ordered by a Dutch court to pay compensation for oil spills in two villages, a ruling that some lawyers say could encourage further cases against multinationals for pollution abroad.

title: German Markets Watchdog Chief Dismissed Over Wirecard Scandal
summary: Ousting of BaFin President Felix Hufeld follows intense criticism over his handling of accounting scandal. BERLIN-The German government on Friday dismissed the head of the country's markets regulator after months of intensifying criticism over the agency's handling of the Wirecard AG scandal.

title: Treasury Unit Ends Probe of H.B. Fuller Without Penalty
summary: The Minnesota company had disclosed in 2018 that its hygiene products might have been resold into Iran, possibly violating U.S. sanctions against that country. Adhesives manufacturer H.B. Fuller Co. said the U.S. Treasury Department has issued it a warning after the company disclosed possible violations of U.S. economic sanctions on Iran.

title: Trial Finds South African Coronavirus Strain Poses Reinfection Risks
summary: People who have already had Covid-19 can be reinfected by the South African variant, a finding that could impact global fight against the pandemic. JOHANNESBURG-A clinical trial of Novavax Inc.'s Covid-19 vaccine in South Africa produced a potentially worrying finding: Among the participants who didn't receive the shot, an earlier Covid-19 infection didn't appear to protect them against catching the disease again from a new strain of the coronavirus now circulating the country.

title: Impeaching and Trying Ex-President Trump
summary: If there are no consequences for subversion and insurrection, it may encourage future presidents to do the same thing.. Your editorial "Trying Mr. Trump, Private Citizen" (Jan. 26) makes the case that a trial may strengthen Mr. Trump. You go through all sorts of scenarios and outcomes and conclude that President Biden should have asked that the trial be dropped. I respectfully disagree.

title: GOP Should Proceed With Newsom's Recall
summary: In none of the examples cited had the recalled officeholder unilaterally closed businesses and kept them closed, bankrupted thousands of businesses and destroy small-business people's lives.. Regarding Joshua Spivak's "The GOP Bid to Boot Gavin Newsom Could Backfire" (Cross Country, Jan. 23): Mr. Spivak recounts several recalls that eventually backfired. But in none of the examples cited had the recalled officeholder unilaterally closed businesses and kept them closed for months, a year or more. Did the previous officeholders bankrupt thousands of businesses and destroy small-business people's lives? Did they fail to provide consistent electricity to thousands of homes? Did they fail to provide a maintenance plan to prevent scores of wildfires destroying thousands of people's homes?

title: U.K. Opens Its Doors to Five Million Hong Kong Residents
summary: Britain's move, prompted by China's security crackdown, is being criticized by Beijing. LONDON-After protests and political upheaval prompted China to impose a tough new security law on Hong Kong last year, Key Yeung uprooted her family and left for England.

title: The New Silicon Valley Perks: Child Care, Financial Planning and Therapy
summary: Instead of using food and foosball tables to keep workers at the office as long as possible, tech companies now seek to offer benefits for work-life balance. When Lolitta Tracy was job hunting last January, the perks she prioritized were catered lunches, commuting benefits and a stipend she put toward yoga classes. Today, nearly a year into the pandemic, she cares more about benefits she can use while working from her two-bedroom apartment in San Jose, Calif., such as free therapy and personalized advice on financial planning.

title: How David Duchovny Became an Accomplished Novelist
summary: The former star of 'The X-Files' has his fourth book in just six years out next week, 'Truly Like Lightning'. A lifetime ago, before he starred in "The X-Files" or "Californication," before his fame as a heartthrob or experiments as a film director, David Duchovny planned to be a writer. As an English literature grad student at Yale in the 1980s, he figured he would make a living as a professor and scribble in his free time. He tinkered with poetry and dabbled in prose, writing a novel that a publisher liked but said needed work. He ground away at a dissertation and started writing plays but sensed that he needed time onstage to hone his ear for dialogue. He tried out for some campus productions, and what began as a lark became a revelation. "I got swept away," Mr. Duchovny, 60, says over the phone from his home in Malibu, Calif.

title: How Apple's Privacy Change Will Hit Facebook's Core Ad Business
summary: New feature on iPhones will limit Facebook's ability to collect data from apps and prove that ads work. Facebook Inc. will suffer damage to its core business when Apple Inc. implements new privacy changes, advertising industry experts say, as it becomes harder for the social-media company to gather user data and prove that ads on its platform work.

title: China Is Now Sending Twitter Users to Prison for Posts Most Chinese Can't See
summary: Resume Subscription. HONG KONG-China's Communist Party is amping up efforts to control its image around the world by jailing Chinese citizens, many of them ordinary people with little influence, who use foreign social media to criticize Chinese leader Xi Jinping and his government.

title: As Markets Soar, More Companies Turn to Shelf Registrations to Prepare Fundraising
summary: Filing the legal paperwork for share sales ahead of time lets companies speed up fundraising in the future. The number of securities filings that let public companies accelerate the process of selling shares in the future is running high as finance executives look to take advantage of buoyant market conditions.

title: Top Islamic State Leader in Iraq Killed in U.S.-Iraqi Strike
summary: Joint operation comes as the Biden administration weighs how to approach Iraq's security problems. BAGHDAD-A joint U.S.-Iraqi military strike killed the top leader of Islamic State in Iraq this week, setting back the extremist group's local leadership as it attempts to stage a bloody resurgence, American and Iraqi officials said Friday.

title: J&J Vaccine Is Still a Win for the Public
summary: Wall Street was disappointed by data from Johnson & Johnson's coronavirus-vaccine candidate, but the shot will play a key role in the public-health effort. Wall Street has crowned its Covid-19 vaccine winners. But one also-ran is still good enough to help get a return to normalcy within sight.

title: A Tale of Two GameStops
summary: Videogame retailer's actual business has become fully decoupled from high-flying stock, but fundamentals have a way of lasting. In all the madness, it has become easy to forget that GameStop is an actual business.

title: 'Dostoevsky in Love' Review: Possessed by Words
summary: Sentenced and reprieved, exiled and returned, Fyodor Dostoevsky made human suffering the center of his work.. 'At different times," writes Alex Christofi in this innovative biography, "all ends of the political spectrum ... allowed themselves to believe that he spoke for them." Such was the capacious mind and fertile genius of Fyodor Mikhailovich Dostoevsky, a titanic figure who, in the baggy monsters of his novels, depicts the intellectual flux of 19th-century Russia alongside the tragedy of every human heart. He was born under Alexander I and died in the cold early weeks of 1881, shortly before an assassin's bomb blew Alexander II to bits along with the old order. But Dostoevsky's work slips the shackles of its period and enters the immortal zone.

title: Men, Women, Dogs, Lists & Charts
summary: Allie Brosh and Liana Finck explore the painful truths of life in cartoons that are also wildly funny.. Since "Brosh" and "Finck" almost rhyme with "brush" and "ink," you might think these two cartoonists, young and female in a male-dominated line of work, go together like, well, brush and ink. Allie Brosh, famous for her blog and her hilarious first book, "Hyperbole and a Half," and Liana Finck, known for her wildly popular Instagram posts, her New Yorker drawings and "Passing for Human: A Graphic Memoir," are actually nothing alike. But they sure have a lot in common.

title: Fiction: 'Fake Accounts' Review
summary: As life goes increasingly virtual, fiction follows it into territory once the domain of the blogger.. The traditional novel of manners and the newly emerging social-media novel have a lot of points in common-an interest in behavioral nuances, relationship dynamics and the distance between private life and public performance-but it's the differences that will force the next vanguard of writers to innovate. First there's the problem of portrayal. In the past, unless the figure was a Tom Ripley-level sociopath, a person could be assumed to possess a stable set of personality traits, whereas for those who live online, identity is lightly worn, ironically constructed and easily discarded. Even trickier is the conundrum of how to dramatize virtual interactions. In practice, contemporary forms of sociability look identical to isolation.

title: Two Books on the Future of Farming
summary: Nutritional, environmental and economic priorities collide wherever seeds are sown.. What would a just food system look like? For Mark Bittman, the author of some 30 books on food, we should start by reducing, if not wholly eliminating, our consumption of junk food. "Engineered edible substances," he calls them in "Animal, Vegetable, Junk: A History of Food, From Sustainable to Suicidal." A "third type of 'food,' "-note his quotation marks-"more akin to poison."

title: Five Best: Alan Allport on the Year 1940
summary: Selected by the author of, most recently, 'Britain at Bay: The Epic Story of the Second World War, 1938-1941.'. By Julian Jackson (2003)

title: The Keto Way: What If Meat Is Our Healthiest Diet?
summary: Eating high-fat, low-carbohydrate foods has helped many people battle obesity, diabetes and other health problems-even as livestock agriculture contributes significantly to greenhouse-gas emissions. Choosing to avoid meat and eat a plant-based diet has never seemed so virtuous and necessary. Between the intrinsic cruelty of industrial livestock production and livestock's climate footprint-estimated by the U.N.'s Food and Agriculture Organization to be 14.5% of all greenhouse gases world-wide, significantly greater than that of plant agriculture-it has become increasingly difficult to defend the place of meat and animal-sourced foods in our diets. Jonathan Safran Foer, the novelist turned animal-rights activist, may have best captured this thinking in his 2019 nonfiction book, "We Are the Weather: Saving the Planet Begins at Breakfast." As he writes, "We cannot keep the kind of meals we have known and also keep the planet we have known. We must either let some eating habits go or let the planet go. It is that straightforward, that fraught."

title: 'Wonder Woman 1984' Delivers Ratings Win for HBO Max
summary: Movie was most-watched content on streaming platforms during Christmas week, Nielsen says, giving boost to fledging service. "Wonder Woman 1984" gave the new HBO Max streaming service a much-needed boost, according to data from Nielsen.

title: Mysteries: 'Blood Grove' Review
summary: Walter Mosley's beloved detective comes to the aid of a troubled Vietnam vet-who may or may not be setting him up.. Los Angeles in 1969 is the setting of "Blood Grove" (Mulholland, 307 pages, $27), Walter Mosley's 15th book featuring African-American private investigator Ezekiel "Easy" Rawlins. Nearing 50, Easy has achieved a certain security; he heads a three-person detective agency, cruises the Sunset Strip in a yellow Rolls Royce and lives (with his 13-year-old adopted daughter) in a well-guarded mountaintop house overlooking the Pacific. He has the leisure to read to his mind's content and cultivate his rooftop rose garden. The only cloud on Easy's horizon is his latest case.

title: FDA Extends Review of Biogen, Eisai's Alzheimer's Drug
summary: Drug candidate to undergo additional three months of review after panel said data didn't show it to be effective. Biogen Inc. and its partner Eisai Co. Ltd. said their Alzheimer's drug candidate will undergo an additional three months of review by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration after a panel of experts in November voted the agency shouldn't approve the drug.

title: Children's Books: And the Winners Are...
summary: Our columnist takes stock of this year's Youth Media Awards, including the Caldecott and Newbery medalists.. In recent years, the selection committees for the most coveted prizes in children's literature have exercised a marked preference for books that celebrate and explore personal identity, especially with regard to race, sex and ethnicity. Given the tightening grip of identity politics on American popular culture, it was no surprise to see the pattern repeat itself this week at the American Library Association's 2021 Youth Media Awards. These are the prizes that give books a lucrative push into schools and libraries and, in the case of the prestigious Caldecott and Newbery medals, emblazon a gold or silver medallion on a book's cover.

title: 'The Ghost of Galileo' Review: 'All Coherence Gone'
summary: A detail in a 17th-century painting inspires a journey into the history of science and the birth of an unsettled new era.. The place: Oriel College, Oxford. The date: sometime between the summer of 1643 and the summer of 1644. A student, snub-nosed, his face pasty as if it hasn't seen sunlight in a while, perches in a large chair, a compass dangling idly from his right hand, the left stuck awkwardly under his cape. His books, a hefty, closed volume weighing down another, open one (not a good way to treat one's books!), sit unattended on a small table that also carries a telescope and a gloomy-looking globe. Behind the boy stands his tutor, right hand resting on that globe, a look of concern on his face. The dark room, shrouded by heavy curtains, matches the pair's melancholy mood. This was not the most promising subject the German-born painter Francis Cleyn, now mostly remembered as a designer of tapestries for Charles I, had ever tackled, and it shows: Just about the brightest thing in the finished work, apart from the men's fashionable collars and cuffs, is that open book.

title: For Teens, a Wild Homeschooling Alternative: A Trip to Costa Rica
summary: Costa Rica has been welcoming high-schoolers back for study abroad programs, tweaked for the Covid era. After Zoom classes, playtime ensues.. SCHOOLING DURING Covid-19 is like an interminable snow day for parents, minus the fun sledding interludes. The mental state of teenagers who are remote-learning by day and TikToking at night might politely be described as "stir crazy." Unsurprisingly, some parents have taken an unusual, even extreme step to earn themselves and their offspring a breather: sending the kids to a Costa Rica eco-preserve.

title: Caterpillar Flags Signs of Recovery Amid Slack Demand
summary: Less construction during the pandemic has hurt machinery sales, but orders have risen. A construction slowdown during the coronavirus pandemic is hurting demand for Caterpillar Inc.'s heavy machinery, but the manufacturer said dealers and customers expect a turnaround this year.

title: The Brewing Battle for Offshore Wind Turbines
summary: World-leader Siemens Gamesa faces growing competition from General Electric and Vestas. Offshore wind turbines have a nice tailwind as politicians around the world clamp down on carbon emissions. But global leader Siemens Gamesa Renewable Energy also needs to watch its back: The likes of General Electric and Vestas Wind Systems are raising their game.

title: Professor Aimed to Break Lawyers' Monopoly on Legal Services
summary: Deborah Rhode, who has died at age 68, worked to help the poor obtain better representation in court. In her four decades as a law professor at Stanford University, Deborah Rhode focused on a paradox: "The nation suffers from an oversupply of lawyers and an undersupply of legal services for people with low or moderate incomes," as she put it in a 2015 book, "The Trouble With Lawyers."

title: Today's Logistics Report: Seeking Steady Shipping Trade; Semi Cell Shortage; GM Driving Electric
summary: Today's Top Supply Chain & Logistics News from WSJ. Sign up: With one click, get this newsletter delivered to your inbox.

title: Andrew Left's Citron Will Stop Publishing Short-Seller Reports
summary: Founder Andrew Left has been the target of ire from stock traders following GameStop reports. A short seller is calling it quits.

title: Household Income, Savings Rose at End of Last Year
summary: Americans' incomes climbed for first time in three months, but spending declined for the second straight month. U.S. household income rose for the first time in three months in December as a new round of government-aid efforts kicked in, priming the economy for stronger growth this year once the pandemic recedes and businesses fully reopen.

title: What's in the Next iPhone? Check Samsung's New Galaxy S21
summary: An in-screen fingerprint sensor, faster 120Hz screens and a crazy zoom camera. Samsung's latest smartphone provides a glimpse at what the next iPhone may look like.. Three seconds. Three whole seconds of my undivided attention. That's how long it takes me to unlock my iPhone when I'm wearing a mask. Face ID fails, and there I am, punching in a passcode like some Neanderthal.

title: Keith Gill Drove the GameStop Reddit Mania. He Talked to the Journal.
summary: Resume Subscription. BOSTON-The investor who helped direct the world's attention to GameStop, leading a horde of online followers in a bizarre market rally that made and lost fortunes from one day to the next, says he's just a normal guy.

title: If the Olympics Don't Go to Tokyo, or Florida, What About My Mom's House?
summary: The Summer Games deny they're looking for a new location. Here's an offer nevertheless.. There's some worry about the Summer Olympics not happening this year in Tokyo and what it would mean for the world of sports. The state of Florida has already stepped in and offered to host, which is very generous and very Florida. Everything is moving to Florida, it seems. Adding a last-minute Olympics is no big whoop.

title: Repeal of State-Tax Deduction Cap Pitched for Covid-19 Relief Bill
summary: Democrats, in control of Congress, see a chance to repeal the $10,000 limit on the state and local tax deduction, but a move may wait until later this year. WASHINGTON-Lawmakers from New York and New Jersey, looking to capitalize on new Democratic majorities in Congress, are trying to repeal the $10,000 cap on the state and local tax deduction as part of a pandemic-relief bill. But the Biden administration has been noncommittal, and the move looks likely to wait until later this year.

title: Facebook to Test News Feed Controls for Advertisers
summary: Marketers have been pressing for more say-so on what their ads appear next to in the feed. Facebook Inc. said it would soon begin building and testing new controls to let marketers keep their ads away from topics they want to avoid.

title: GameStop, Koss, Bed Bath & Beyond, AMC: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: Robinhood Markets, a popular venue for online traders, said late Thursday it would reinstate some trading in stocks that it had curbed earlier. Here's what we're watching ahead of Friday's opening bell.

title: China's HNA Says Creditors Filed Petition for Its Bankruptcy
summary: Development adds to woes of what was once one of China's most acquisitive companies. Embattled Chinese conglomerate HNA Group Co. said some of its creditors have filed a court petition for its bankruptcy and reorganization after it failed to repay its debts on time.

title: Eli Lilly Profit Rises, Helped by Covid-19 Drug Sales
summary: Antibody drug bamlanivimab brought in world-wide revenue of $871.2 million, contributing much of the company's 22% quarterly revenue growth. Eli Lilly and Co. reported a 41% rise in its quarterly profit on Friday, boosted by strong sales of its Covid-19 antibody treatment and higher demand for its diabetes drugs.

title: From Billie Eilish and Rosalía to Olivia Rodrigo, the Best Songs You Should Be Listening To Right Now
summary: New year, new music. Here's WSJ.'s monthly roundup of new pop releases: everything that's grabbing our attention, making us think or getting us dancing.. There are several causes you could pin to the breakout success of "Drivers License," the first single from pop singer and Disney+ actress Olivia Rodrigo. Speculative fan theories, a public endorsement from Taylor Swift and TikToks galore contributed to the track's debut at No. 1 on the Billboard Hot 100. But as Kevin Weatherly, Spotify's head of North American programming, told WSJ., "There is something magical that's connecting, and people are responding to that. It goes beyond her following. It's about the music."

title: Symone Is The New Fashion Queen of 'RuPaul's Drag Race'
summary: The 26-year-old drag queen is winning over fans with her runway looks and comedic chops.. One night in 2013, a queen was born in Little Rock, Arkansas. Reggie Gavin walked onstage at Triniti Nightclub to Jessie J's "Domino" wearing a Forever 21 dress and a "shake-and-go" wig and became the performer Symone for the first time.

title: Azerbaijan Struggles to Heal After War
summary: Resume Subscription. BAKU, Azerbaijan-Last October, Yusif Budaqov, a young sniper fighting in Azerbaijan's army in the battle for Nagorno-Karabakh, was killed two weeks after his 23rd birthday, one of thousands of casualties in the conflict with Armenia.

title: Insiders at GameStop, BlackBerry, LaCroix Maker Sit on Big Stock Gains
summary: Reddit-fueled trading in long-struggling companies boost holdings of CEOs and directors, though few have reported cashing in. Retail day traders and Reddit stock pickers aren't the only ones riding a surge in stock market gains. So are some chief executives and board members at long-struggling companies.

title: Iowa Democrats, Republicans Gear Up to Protect Caucuses
summary: A botched Democratic vote-counting effort in last year's presidential campaign boosted skepticism about the state's complex process. At a time when bipartisanship is in short supply, Democrats and Republicans are united in Iowa behind defending the state's political golden goose: the first-in-the-nation presidential caucuses.

title: Covid-19 Vaccine Experiences From Around the U.S.
summary: Eight vaccine recipients describe the process of getting their shots. As Americans navigate the sometimes complicated routes to getting vaccinated against Covid-19, some recipients described their experiences of getting their shots. The vaccine rollout in the U.S. has been managed by individual states instead of the federal government, and the process has been unclear and inconsistent for many people. Here are the stories of several people who succeeded in getting through the maze.

title: The NBA's Best Young Stars Loved the Same Player. He Hated the NBA.
summary: Luka Doncic and Giannis Antetokounmpo grew up watching Vassilis Spanoulis. He played one season in the NBA. He's also responsible for the future of the league.. Every basketball player is a reflection of basketball players before him. So when the hosts of "Inside the NBA" recently interviewed Luka Doncic, they were curious if the Dallas Mavericks' superstar modeled his game after the Americans or Europeans he grew up watching.

title: Surge in Trading Volume Causes Glitches for High-Speed Traders
summary: Brokers were unable to route investors' orders to Susquehanna and Wolverine. High-speed trading firms that execute orders for individual investors faced technical hiccups this week because of exploding volume in GameStop Corp. , AMC Entertainment Holdings Inc. and other popular stocks.

title: For Golf, Covid Is Even Better Than Tiger
summary: The socially distant sport got a shot in the arm from the pandemic, and demographic trends could take it to new heights. Golf was just working its way out of the rough when the pandemic hit. After an initial shock last spring, the sport is poised for its best year since Tiger Woods was at the height of his popularity two decades ago. There is still plenty of green for investors to aim for.

title: China's Top Bottled-Water Group Swells to an $85 Billion Valuation
summary: Nongfu Spring's profit margins and growth potential have impressed investors and analysts. Exuberance and a shortage of tradable shares have helped, too.. Investor exuberance about China's biggest bottled-water company, Nongfu Spring Co. , has combined with a shortage of tradable shares to send its stock soaring.

title: How to Reopen Schools? Officials Try Financial Lures, Threats
summary: New plans from states and Biden administration deploy carrots-and sticks-to get students back into classrooms. In an effort to get more children out of living rooms and into classrooms, President Biden and state lawmakers have begun pushing financial incentives-as well as threats to cut funding-to get school districts to swing their doors open.

title: McKinsey Is in Settlement Talks With States Over Opioid Work
summary: Potential deal comes on the heels of new documents that detail McKinsey's work to boost OxyContin sales for Purdue Pharma. McKinsey & Co. is close to reaching a settlement with state attorneys general over advice it gave to Purdue Pharma LP and other opioid manufacturers that have been targeted by states over their alleged role in fueling the nation's opioid crisis, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: 'An Inventory of Losses' Review: Only a Memory
summary: In the fragmentary remains of unique things and places lost to time, a writer finds insights and opportunity.. Did you know that the now-extinct Caspian tiger was last sighted in Iran in 1964; fragments of third-century writing from the founder of the dualistic religion Manicheanism were unearthed in the Egyptian desert in 1929; that the French painter Hubert Robert, anticipating his likely beheading in 1794, built a miniature guillotine in his cell to study "the workings of the apparatus"; or that the physicist Otto von Guericke in 1663 discovered the "skeleton of a unicorn"?

title: Novavax Vaccine Is 89% Effective Against Covid-19 in U.K. Study
summary: The vaccine was less effective in a separate, middle-stage study in South Africa. Novavax Inc. said Thursday its Covid-19 vaccine was 89.3% effective at protecting people from the disease in an interim analysis from its late-stage study in the U.K., where a worrisome strain of the coronavirus has been circulating.

title: Robinhood, Other Brokerages Restrict Trading on GameStop, AMC
summary: Move comes amid extreme volatility this week as once-unpopular stocks have soared. Popular online brokerages restricted trading in highflying stocks including GameStop Corp. and AMC Entertainment Holdings Inc., sapping some of the euphoria around shares of companies that individual investors have sent skyrocketing in recent days.

title: Chernova's Take: When to Restrict Buying a Stock? Trading App Public Makes Different Calls With Hertz and GameStop
summary: The contrast in the stance by the social-trading startup shows tech-founder struggles on when to act. When Robinhood Markets Inc. and some other brokerages halted buying of highly volatile stocks including GameStop Corp. on Thursday, users angry at the decisions flocked to Public Holdings Inc., a smaller social-trading app backed by Accel, Greycroft and other venture-capital firms.

title: Cicely Tyson, Trailblazing Actor, Dead at 96
summary: She received an Oscar nomination for 'Sounder' in 1973 and won a Tony Award 40 years later for 'The Trip to Bountiful'. NEW YORK-Cicely Tyson, the pioneering Black actor who gained an Oscar nomination for her role as the sharecropper's wife in "Sounder," a Tony Award in 2013 at age 88 and touched TV viewers' hearts in "The Autobiography of Miss Jane Pittman," died Thursday at age 96.

title: Defense Chief Holds Up Trump Nominees to Pentagon Boards
summary: Lloyd Austin is reviewing policies 'across the department,' Pentagon spokesman says. Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin has suspended the onboarding process for several last-minute Trump administration nominees to Pentagon advisory boards, defense officials said, effectively preventing them from being seated.

title: Pakistan's Supreme Court Orders Release of Man Convicted in Killing of WSJ Reporter Daniel Pearl
summary: Omar Sheikh is cleared of any role in the journalist's kidnapping and death after 18 years in prison. ISLAMABAD, Pakistan-The country's Supreme Court ordered the release of the man convicted in 2002 of orchestrating the abduction and killing of Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl after effectively clearing him of wrongdoing in the case.

title: Columbus Police Chief Ousted After Officers Killed Black Men
summary: Mayor's move also follows criticism of police department for using tear gas on demonstrators. The mayor of Columbus, Ohio, ousted the city's police chief Thursday, citing a failure to implement changes at the department and a citywide loss in confidence.

title: Two Lose Attempt to Avoid Extradition in Ghosn Case
summary: Federal judge rules against emergency petition by suspects tied to flight from Japan by former auto titan Carlos Ghosn. BOSTON-A former Green Beret and his son moved a step closer to being extradited to Japan to face criminal charges in the dramatic escape of former auto titan Carlos Ghosn, after a federal judge ruled against the duo's latest legal challenge.
